details.title: Efficient Reliability Assessment of Redundant Systems Subject to Imperfect Fault Coverage Using Binary Decision Diagrams

authors.affiliation: Northrop Grumman Corp., Los Angeles, CA

p: Albert Myers retired in 2006 as the corporate vice president of strategy and technology for the Northrop Grumman Corporation. He also served as a B-2 chief project engineer, deputy program manager, and vice president of test operations for the B-2 Division. Myers earned BS, and MS degrees in Mechanical Engineering from the University of Idaho, and was a Sloan Fellow at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Myers is an elected member of the National Academy of Engineering. He served from 1989 through 1998 on the NASA Aeronautics Advisory Board. He received the NASA Exceptional Service Medal, and the 1981 Dryden Director's Award; and was elected to the University of Idaho Alumni Hall of Fame in 1997.

authors.name: Albert Myers

p: Antoine Rauzy received his PhD in computer sciences in 1989, and a “habilitation à diriger des recherches” in 1996. He joined the Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique in 1991, and the Institut de Mathématiques de Luminy in 2000. His topics of research are reliability engineering, formal methods, and algorithms. He has authored more than 100 articles for international conferences, and journals. He has designed various software products including the fault tree assessment tool Aralia. Since 2001, he has been the president of the ARBoost Technologies Company.

details.abstract: Systems requiring very high levels of reliability, such as aircraft controls or spacecraft, often use redundancy to achieve their requirements. This paper provides highly efficient techniques for computing the reliability of redundant systems involving simple k-out-of-n arrangements, and those involving complex structures which may include imbedded k-out-of-n structures. Techniques for modeling systems subject to imperfect fault coverage must be appropriate to the redundancy management architecture utilized by the system. Systems for which coverage can be associated with each of the redundant components, perhaps taking advantage of the component's built-in test capability, are modeled with what we term element level coverage (ELC); while systems which utilize majority voting for the selection from among redundant components are modeled with fault level coverage (FLC). In FLC, systems coverage is a function of the fault sequence, i.e., coverage will be greater for the initial faults which can utilize voting for redundant component selection, but will have a lower coverage value when the system must select from among the last two operational components. Occasionally, FLC systems can be adequately modeled using a simplified version of FLC in which it can be assumed that the initial fault coverage values are unity. This model is called one-on-level coverage (OLC). The FLC algorithms provided in this paper are of particular importance for the correct modeling of systems which utilize voting to select from among their redundant elements. While combinatorial, and recursive techniques for modeling ELC, FLC, and OLC have been previously reported, this paper presents new table-based algorithms, and binary decision diagram-based algorithms for these models which have superior computational complexity. The algorithms presented here provide the ability to analyse large, and complex systems very efficiently, in fact with a computational complexity comparable to the best available techniques for systems with perfect fault coverage.

references.title:
Reliability modeling techniques for self-repairing
computer systems

context.text: The importance of including coverage, the probability of correctly detecting, isolating, and accommodating the failure of a redundant component, has been well understood for some time [1]–[3].

references.text: W. G. Bourcius, W. C. Carter, P. R. Schneider, "Reliability modeling techniques for self-repairing computer systems", 24th Ann. ACM Nat'l Conf., pp. 295-309, 1969.

references.title:
Reliability modeling for fault-tolerant
computers

context.text: The importance of including coverage, the probability of correctly detecting, isolating, and accommodating the failure of a redundant component, has been well understood for some time [1]–[2][3].

Bouricius et. al. pointed out in 1971 [2] that “Perhaps the biggest danger [in the design of redundant systems] is that [of] assuming perfect coverage \$(c=1)\$, when the coverage is only ‘near’ perfect, [which] produces grossly inaccurate results. \$\ldots\$ A value of \$c=0.99\$ is not anywhere near perfect.”.

links.abstract: Reliability modeling and the mathematical equations involved are discussed for general computer systems organized to be fault tolerant. This paper summarizes the work done over the last four years on mathematical reliability modeling by the authors.

references.text: W. G. Bourcius, W. C. Carter, D. C. Jessep, P. R. Schneider, A. B. Wadia, "Reliability modeling for fault-tolerant computers", IEEE Trans. Computers, vol. C-20, pp. 1306-1311, 1971.

references.title:
The concept of coverage and its effect on
the reliability model of a repairable system

context.text: The importance of including coverage, the probability of correctly detecting, isolating, and accommodating the failure of a redundant component, has been well understood for some time [1]–[3].

links.abstract: Duplication is a technique frequently employed to achieve high reliability for a repairable system. Although the philosophy of duplication is that it takes two faults to place a system out of service, there are generally some critical single faults that cause a system failure. This paper considers the effect of such a set of faults on a repairable system's reliability. It is shown that even a small number of such faults may severely degrade the mean time to system failure and the expected downti...

references.text: T. F. Arnold, "The concept of coverage and its effect on the reliability model of a repairable system", IEEE Trans. Computers, vol. C-22, pp. 325-339, 1973.

references.title:
<ref_formula><tex>$k$</tex></ref_formula>-out-of-<ref_formula>
<tex>$n$</tex></ref_formula>:G system reliability with imperfect fault coverage

context.text:
The following classes, adopting the taxonomy from [4], are discussed: 

PFC
Perfect Fault Coverage.
Combinatorial ELC routines were presented in [4], and a table-based code is presented in [11].
Combinatorial FLC models were initially presented in [4], while the application of the separable SEA technique was applied to FLC models in [13].
By treating the coverage values as Bernoulli state variables, it is possible to derive combinatorial IFC models for both ELC, and FLC systems [4].
The taxonomy presented hereafter is mainly taken from [4].
Combinatorial algorithms for the assessment of IFC systems were presented in [4].
However, the IFC algorithms presented here are computationally more efficient than those in [11], and are far more efficient than the combinatorial functions presented in [4].

The table-based FLC & OLC algorithms provided here produce the same results as the \${\rm R}_{\rm FLC}\$ & \${\rm R}_{\rm OLC}\$ combinatorial functions given in [4], but have far superior computational complexity.
In this paper, we have utilized a taxonomy describing two important classes of imperfect fault coverage for modeling the reliability of redundant systems suggested in [4].
The table-based algorithms presented here have substantially better computational complexity than the combinatorial, and recursive imperfect fault coverage models previously disclosed in [4].

links.abstract: Systems requiring very high levels of reliability, such as aircraft controls or spacecraft, often use redundancy to achieve their requirements. Reliability models for such redundant systems have been widely treated in the literature. These models describe k-out-of-n:G systems, where n is the number of components in the system, and k is the minimum number of components that must work if the overall system is to work. Most of this literature treats the perfect fault coverage case, meaning that the...

references.text: A. F. Myers, "\$k\$-out-of- \$n\$:G system reliability with imperfect fault coverage", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 56, no. 3, pp. 464-473, Sept. 2007.

references.title: HiRel: Hybrid Automated Reliability Predictor (HARP) Integrated Reliability Tool System (Version 7.0),

context.text: In the terminology used with HARP [5], ELC models are known as single-fault models, and FLC models are termed multi-fault models.
Historically, the few examples of FLC analysis have used behavioral decomposition [12], and Markov chain-based techniques [5].

references.text: S. J. Bavuso, E. Rothmann, J. Dugan, K. S. Trivedi, N. Mittal, M. A. Boyd, R. M. Geist, M. D. Smotherman, HiRel: Hybrid Automated Reliability Predictor (HARP) Integrated Reliability Tool System (Version 7.0), vol. 1, Nov. 1994.

references.title:
Coverage modeling for dependability analysis
of fault-tolerant systems

context.text: Key developments in the analysis of ELC systems have included Markov chain-based solutions [6], behavioral decomposition techniques [7], multi-state combinatorial techniques [8], and the separable technique using conditional probability known as SEA [9].

links.abstract: Several different models for predicting coverage in a fault-tolerant system, including models for permanent, intermittent, and transient errors, are discussed. Markov, semi-Markov, nonhomogeneous Markov, and extended stochastic Petri net models for computing coverage are developed. Two types of events that interfere with recovery are examined; and methods for modeling such events, whether they are deterministic or random, are given. The sensitivity of system reliability/availability to the cover...

references.text: J. B. Dugan, K. S. Trivedi, "Coverage modeling for dependability analysis of fault-tolerant systems", IEEE Trans. Computers, vol. 38, pp. 775-787, Jun. 1989.

references.title:
Decomposition in reliability analysis of
fault tolerant systems

context.text: Key developments in the analysis of ELC systems have included Markov chain-based solutions [6], behavioral decomposition techniques [7], multi-state combinatorial techniques [8], and the separable technique using conditional probability known as SEA [9].

links.abstract: Two important problems which arise in modeling fault-tolerant systems with ultra-high reliability requirements are discussed. 1) Any analytic model of such a system has a large number of states, making the solution computationally intractable. This leads to the need for decomposition techniques. 2) The common assumption of exponential holding times in the states is intolerable while modeling such systems. Approaches to solving this problem are reviewed. A major notion described in the attempt to...

references.text: K. S. Trivedi, R. M. Geist, "Decomposition in reliability analysis of fault tolerant systems", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-32, pp. 463-468, Dec. 1983.

references.title:
A combinatorial approach to modeling imperfect
coverage

context.text: Key developments in the analysis of ELC systems have included Markov chain-based solutions [6], behavioral decomposition techniques [7], multi-state combinatorial techniques [8], and the separable technique using conditional probability known as SEA [9].

links.abstract: A new algorithm combines a coverage model with a combinatorial model to compute system unreliability. Its advantage is that for a class of computer systems, it is simpler than current algorithms. The method applies to combinatorial models which can generate cutsets for the system. This set of cutsets is augmented with cutsets representing the uncovered failures of the system. The resulting set is manipulated by combining standard multi-state and sum-of-disjoint products solution techniques. It i...

references.text: S. A. Doyle, J. B. Dugan, F. A. Patterson-Hine, "A combinatorial approach to modeling imperfect coverage", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 44, pp. 87-94.

references.title:
A separable method for incorporating imperfect
fault-coverage in combinatorial models

context.text: Key developments in the analysis of ELC systems have included Markov chain-based solutions [6], behavioral decomposition techniques [7], multi-state combinatorial techniques [8], and the separable technique using conditional probability known as SEA [9].
They can be implemented using a standard BDD package, and require no special handling of component reliabilities or the resulting system reliability, such as required for application of SEA [9].
System evaluation using SEA [9] has the same number of system states as the corresponding PFC system, while the techniques outlined in this paper treat the coverage values as additional states.

The ELC functions presented above produce results identical to those computed using the SEA algorithm [9], and have the advantage of requiring no pre-processing of component reliabilities, or post-processing of the resulting system reliabilities.

links.abstract: This paper presents a new method for incorporating imperfect FC (fault coverage) into a combinatorial model. Imperfect FC, the probability that a single malicious fault can thwart automatic recovery mechanisms, is important to accurate reliability assessment of fault-tolerant computer systems. Until recently, it was thought that the consideration of this probability necessitated a Markov model rather than the simpler (and usually faster) combinatorial model. SEA, the new approach, separates the ...

references.text: S. V. Amari, J. B. Dugan, R. B. Misra, "A separable method for incorporating imperfect fault-coverage in combinatorial models", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 48, no. 3, pp. 267-274, Sept. 1999.

references.title:
OBDD-based evaluation of reliability and
importance measures for multistate systems subject to imperfect fault coverage

context.text: BDD techniques are presented in [10] for multi-state system reliability subject to ELC, also using the SEA algorithm.

links.abstract: Algorithms for evaluating the reliability of a complex system such as a multistate fault-tolerant computer system have become more important. They are designed to obtain the complete results quickly and accurately even when there exist a number of dependencies such as shared loads (reconfiguration), degradation, and common-cause failures. This paper presents an efficient method based on ordered binary decision diagram (OBDD) for evaluating the multistate system reliability and the Griffith's imp...

references.text: Y. R. Chang, S. V. Amari, S. Y. Kuo, "OBDD-based evaluation of reliability and importance measures for multistate systems subject to imperfect fault coverage", IEEE Trans. Dependable and Secure Comp., vol. 2, no. 4, pp. 336-347, Oct.Dec. 2005.

references.title:
Assessment of redundant systems with imperfect coverage
by means of binary decision diagrams

context.text: Combinatorial ELC routines were presented in [4], and a table-based code is presented in [11].
A table-based routine is given in [11].
The table-based codes reported in [11] have somewhat better complexity, \${\cal O}(n\cdot(k-1))\$ for \$k\$-out-of-\$n\$: F systems.
It was shown in [11] that table-based codes of a similar nature could be used to compute the reliability of ELC & FLC \$k\$-out-of-\$n\$: F systems.
In this paper, we present table-based codes for IFC systems which are similar to, but different from, those of [11].
Recursive & table-based IFC algorithms were presented in [11] for \$k\$-out-of-\$n\$: F systems.
However, the IFC algorithms presented here are computationally more efficient than those in [11], and are far more efficient than the combinatorial functions presented in [4].

The Aralia implementation was done using \$k\$-out-of-\$n\$: F gates as described in [11], while the FCASE results utilized the \$k\$-out-of-\$n\$: G algorithms in the fashion illustrated in Section VIII.

references.text: A. F. Myers, A. Rauzy, "Assessment of redundant systems with imperfect coverage by means of binary decision diagrams", Reliability Engineering and System Safety, Mar. 2006.

references.title:
Extended behavioral decomposition for estimating ultrahigh
reliability

context.text: Historically, the few examples of FLC analysis have used behavioral decomposition [12], and Markov chain-based techniques [5].

links.abstract: Limitations of some analytic techniques in approximating the reliability of life-critical electronic systems are discussed, and a framework for the specification of recovery and fault- handling submodels is suggested. The framework makes full use of the instantaneous jump theorem by viewing the collection of interfering, premature exits from any fault handling and recovery submodel as defining a new, competing process submodel. This approach allows a greater flexibility in submodel representatio...

references.text: R. Geist, "Extended behavioral decomposition for estimating ultrahigh reliability", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 40, pp. 22-28, Apr. 1991.

references.title:
An efficient algorithm to analyze new imperfect fault coverage
models

context.text: Combinatorial FLC models were initially presented in [4], while the application of the separable SEA technique was applied to FLC models in [13].

links.abstract: Fault tolerance has been an essential architectural attribute for achieving high reliability in many critical applications of digital systems. Automatic recovery and reconfiguration mechanisms play a crucial role in implementing fault tolerance because an uncovered fault may lead to a system or subsystem failure even when adequate redundancy exists. In addition, an excessive level of redundancy may even reduce the system reliability. Therefore, an accurate analysis must account for not only the ...

references.text: S. V. Amari, A. Myers, A. Rauzy, "An efficient algorithm to analyze new imperfect fault coverage models", Reliability and Maintainability Symposium, 2007.

references.title:
New insights in the assessment of <ref_formula><tex>$k$</tex>
</ref_formula>-out-of- <ref_formula><tex>$n$</tex></ref_formula> and related
systems

context.text: An efficient table-based algorithm for computing the reliability of \$k\$-out-of-\$n\$ PFC systems was given in [14].

The table-based routines have been derived, using an approach proposed in [14], from the corresponding recursive function by “memorizing” intermediate results in a table, \$P\$, which is used to store the system's reliability given that \$0,1,\ldots,n-k\$ components have failed.

references.text: Y. Dutuit, A. Rauzy, "New insights in the assessment of \$k\$ -out-of- \$n\$ and related systems", Reliability Engineering and System Safety, vol. 72, no. 3, pp. 303-314, 2001.

references.title:
A combinatorial-models and coverage: A binary decision diagram
(BDD) approach

context.text: Neither do they require special modification to the computation of system unreliability from the BDD to include the possibility of uncovered failures, and the mutual exclusivity of covered or uncovered failures, as in [15].

links.abstract: This paper presents the DREDD (Dependability and Risk Analysis using Decision Diagrams) algorithm which incorporates coverage modeling into a BDD solution of a combinatorial model. The DREDD algorithm takes advantage of the efficiency of the BDD solution approach and the increased accuracy afforded by coverage modeling. BDDs have been used to find exact solutions for extremely large systems, including those with as many as 10/sup 20/ prime implicants. Including coverage in this process will incr...

references.text: S. A. Doyle, J. B. Dugan, M. Boyd, "A combinatorial-models and coverage: A binary decision diagram (BDD) approach", Proc. Ann. Reliability and Maintainability Symposium, pp. 82-89, 1995.

references.title: Fault tree and imperfect coverage

context.text: While the \$(n-1)\$ coverage values required for a FLC model can be estimated using any appropriate technique, the approach illustrated in this paper uses a near-coincident fault model [16], [17].

links.abstract: A new algorithm is presented for solving the fault tree. The algorithm includes the dynamic behavior of the fault/error handling model but obviates the need for the Markov chain solution. As the state space is expanded in a breadth-first search (the same is done in the conversion to a Markov chain), the state's contribution to each future state is calculated exactly. A dynamic state truncation technique is also presented; it produces bounds on the unreliability of the system by considering only ...

references.text: J. B. Dugan, "Fault tree and imperfect coverage", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 38, pp. 177-185, Jun. 1989.

references.title: Probability and Statistics with Reliability, Queuing and Computer Science Applications

context.text: While the \$(n-1)\$ coverage values required for a FLC model can be estimated using any appropriate technique, the approach illustrated in this paper uses a near-coincident fault model [16], [17].

references.text: K. S. Trivedi, Probability and Statistics with Reliability Queuing and Computer Science Applications, 2002, John Wiley & Sons.

references.title:
Graph based algorithms for Boolean function
manipulation

context.text: The use of Reduced Order Binary Decision Diagrams (ROBDD), often shortened to BDD, were initially developed as a tool for validating VLSI circuitry design by Bryant [18].

links.abstract: In this paper we present a new data structure for representing Boolean functions and an associated set of manipulation algorithms. Functions are represented by directed, acyclic graphs in a manner similar to the representations introduced by Lee [1] and Akers [2], but with further restrictions on the ordering of decision variables in the graph. Although a function requires, in the worst case, a graph of size exponential in the number of arguments, many of the functions encountered in typical app...

references.text: R. Bryant, "Graph based algorithms for Boolean function manipulation", IEEE Trans. Computers, vol. 35, pp. 677-691, Aug. 1986.

references.title: Efficient implementation of a BDD package

context.text: An excellent explanation for the implementation of a BDD package is provided in [19].

links.abstract: Efficient manipulation of Boolean functions is an important component of many computer-aided design tasks. A package for manipulating Boolean functions based on the reduced, ordered, binary decision diagram (ROBDD) representation is described. The package is based on an efficient implementation of the if-then-else (ITE) operator. A hash table is used to maintain a strong canonical form in the ROBDD and memory use is improved by merging the hash table and the ROBDD into a hybrid data structure. A...

references.text: K. Brace, R. Ruddel, R. Bryant, "Efficient implementation of a BDD package", Proc. 27th ACM/IEEE Design Automation Conference, pp. 40-45, 1990.

references.title: New algorithms for fault tree analysis

context.text: Since their introduction in reliability analysis, they have proved to be the most efficient technique to assess fault trees, and system reliability [20].

references.text: A. Rauzy, "New algorithms for fault tree analysis", Reliability Engineering and System Safety, vol. 5, no. 59, pp. 203-211, 1993.
